CANTO I.</br>As the bee, in woodbine shade,</br>Wanders o'er the dewy blade,</br>Sipping balm, or juicy sweet,</br>From lily, rose, or violet;</br>So I, with Fancy, chanc'd to stray</br>Erewhile in Pleasure's flowery way,</br>Where Beauty and the Graces rove,</br>Smiling, hand in hand with Love;</br>And fairy-featur'd Hope is seen,</br>Lightly skipping o'er the green,</br>Scattering many an am'rous wile,</br>The winning look, the pleading air,</br>Of the young timid yielding fair,</br>And Modesty's approving smile.

The opening bloom on HARRIET'S cheek,</br>Her dewy lips, and snowy neck,</br>The swelling of her bosom bare</br>Half seen beneath her auburn hair</br>And glowing softness of her arm,</br>And graceful step of heav'nly charm—</br>First allur'd my thoughts to rove</br>In the wild'ring ways of Love.</br>But HARRIET'S soft and polish'd frame</br>Only shone with Beauty's flame,</br>And conceal'd a vulgar mind,</br>Dead to every charm refin'd,</br>From Wit or Sentiment that flows,</br>Or blithe-ey'd Cheerfulness bestows.

Not long I saunter'd with this fair,</br>Till ANNA'S gay enam'ring air,</br>And flowing mirth, and sweetest song,</br>And artless prattle of her tongue,</br>Won my heart ere well aware.</br>No soul has he, who could have seen</br>The Graces rising in her mien,</br>As often, in sequester'd grove,</br>At evening time, we talk'd of love;</br>Soft mingling with a tender sense</br>Of modesty and innocence,</br>The jocund leer, the dimpled smile,</br>And nod, and wink, replete with guile,</br>Th' inviting glance, when transport high</br>Wanton'd in her azure eye,—</br>And yet for ANNA never sigh.</br>Oft would that eye in fondness roll,</br>As by my side she sat reclin'd,</br>My arms around her waist entwin'd,</br>While many a kiss I slyly stole.</br>Anon I felt unknown alarms,</br>And fell a victim to her charms;</br>Nor ever thought a nymph so gay,</br>In triumph, would her swain betray;</br>Or that the tear should e'er bedew</br>My bosom, when she prov'd untrue.

With Beauty cloy'd, and being bit</br>By the serpent call'd Coquette,</br>Pensive, I left the flowery green,</br>Where I had sported many a day,</br>Following Pleasure's transient ray,</br>And, heedless, sought the dell of Spleen;</br>Where Prudery, in gloomy pride,</br>And scowling Apathy, reside.

Soon roaming o'er a desert dale,</br>Where never breathes the genial gale,</br>Where hemlock beds with reptiles teem</br>As moisten'd by a muddy stream,</br>And vapours rise in volumes grey,</br>Clouding the cheerful face of day;</br>By chance I spied the prudish maid</br>In snowy vestment prim array'd:</br>No flounce or fold was pinn'd awry,</br>So much she studied nicety;</br>Her jetty hair, sleek'd up behind,</br>Ne'er floated in the sportive wind,</br>Nor modest handkerchief reveal'd</br>What young coquettes scarce wish conceal'd:</br>Like them, she never knew the grace</br>Of pleasing, or the bland embrace</br>Of paramour; nay deem'd amiss</br>The side long glance, the yielding kiss.

As I approach'd this rigid dame,</br>With fault'ring step, and shudd'ring frame;</br>On me, in sullen discontent,</br>Her grey unsparkling eye was bent:</br>Nor from her seat she deign'd to rise,</br>Nor welcome brighten'd in her eyes;</br>And looks demure, and squeamish pride,</br>The place of every smile supplied.

But when I scornful by her past,</br>A simpering leer on me she cast,</br>Good-humour gleam'd upon her mein</br>And mingled with a glance serene;</br>While in a trim affected air,</br>Much she warn'd me to beware</br>Of Pleasure's gay enchanting wiles,</br>And young-ey'd Beauty's cheerful smiles,</br>Of winning Mirth, and Wit's sly graces,</br>And Love's unsolemniz'd embraces;</br>Then much she talk'd of Virtue's power</br>To guard us in th' impassion'd hour,</br>Of Prudence, and of Friendship's flame,</br>And meek Reserve, and virgin Shame,</br>And Chastity's dear honour'd name.

Wearied with Prudery's fretful tale,</br>On a bank as I repos'd</br>Amide the solitary vale,</br>Dewy Sleep my eye-lids clos'd.</br>Descending from the climes of light,</br>Anon a Figure caught my sight:</br>On a fleecy cloud she rode,</br>A sky-wove robe around her flow'd,</br>In folds so fine, it more reveal'd</br>Her mingling beauties, than conceal'd:</br>So shine the lily of the dale,</br>Array'd in Nature's softest hue,</br>When opening to the morning gale</br>'Tis thinly veil'd in lucid dew.</br>Love's softning blush, and Beauty's flame,</br>Brighten'd on her graceful frame;</br>And life's cerulean veins were seen</br>Meand'ring thro' her snowy skin:</br>In humid lustre, mildly shone,</br>Her timid eye; and "for her crown,</br>The Red-breast, and the Turtle-dove,"</br>Mimosa's trembling leaves had wove.</br>When from her bosom burst the sigh,</br>Or secret anguish fill'd her eye,</br>The leaves, as conscious of her woe,</br>No more in native verdure blow,</br>But seem in sympathy to share</br>Her pang of sorrow and of care;</br>Yet soon as Grief no more is seen</br>To o'ercast her lovely mien,</br>Her cheeks their vivid glow regain,</br>And rapture throbs in every vein;</br>Again the leaves begin to bloom,</br>And a fresher green resume.

Alighting form her chariot bright,</br>In all her charms she now appear'd,</br>And, smiling on me with delight,</br>Thus she express'd her fond regard,</br>In strains more melancholy sweet</br>Than ever charm'd a mortal yet,</br>Even tho' he chanc'd to saunter nigh</br>The scene of midnight minstrelsy,</br>When rev'lling in the Moon's soft beam,</br>By haunted mountain, wood, or stream,</br>In green and gold the Fairies gleam.
"Not distant far, in blissful grove,</br>Beauty, and Harmony, and Love,</br>With Pleasure dwell — thence I descend,</br>Thy heavenly Guardian and thy Friend."

"'Tis mine to waken young Desire;</br>The soul of Genius to inspire;</br>On playful Childhood's way to strew</br>Gay Fancy's flowers of many a hue;</br>And o'er the infant mind diffuse</br>The hallow'd influence of the Muse.</br>Long have you felt the mystic glow,</br>That on my fav'rites I bestow;</br>The transport of the soul refin'd,</br>And anguish of the feeling mind,</br>Successive thrill your trembling frame;</br>For transient pleasure, transient pain,</br>Mark the bosom where I reign—</br>Hence, SENSIBILITY my name.</br>'Twas I who led you first to rove</br>Among the myrtle bowers of Love;</br>Who, from young HARRIET'S blooming frame,</br>Inspir'd a bright, tho' transient flame:</br>That you, my fav'rite, hence might know,</br>Tho' the soft cheek of beauty glow,</br>Like vernal rose of freshest hue,</br>Blushing beneath the morning dew;</br>Yet soon the deepest tints will fade,</br>And soon the softest charms will cloy,</br>Should SENSIBILITY ne'er shed</br>A portion of ethereal joy,</br>Flowing from my breath refin'd,</br>Into the yielding female mind;</br>Thence, with inspiration warm,</br>To animate the polish'd form;</br>To bid the smiling Graces rise,</br>And pour o'er Beauty's native bloom</br>A softer glow, and to illume</br>With living fire responsive eyes.

"And when you saw these charms combin'd,</br>Beaming from ANNA'S gayer mind,</br>In winning smile, or am'rous glance,</br>Inviting Lovers' soft advance,</br>By me, the sly coquetish art,</br>You deem'd the language of her heart:</br>And when the maiden prov'd untrue,</br>'Twas I who bade the tear bedew</br>Your throbbing breast; till, more serene,</br>You saunter'd to this gloomy scene;</br>And here, lest Prudery's sullen strain,</br>Heard lately murm'ring from the plain,</br>Should have seduc'd you as a slave</br>To Apathy's infernal cave,</br>I stretch'd your limbs in bland repose,</br>And o'er you shed Sleep's balmy dews</br>From yonder cloud — hence you may learn</br>Thy heav'nly Guardian's fond concern;</br>And, from your recent anguish, know</br>How near the hidden thorn of woe,</br>The vernal buds of pleasure blow:</br>How well the light coquette can feign</br>Herself a follower in my train,</br>Glowing with conquest to decoy</br>Unwary youth to vales of Joy;</br>And as he roams the blissful scene</br>To lead him to the dell of Spleen:</br>Or should he clime the airy steep</br>Of Rapture — giddy with the sight,</br>Ah me!  he sinks to endless night,</br>Where Melancholy wakes to weep.

"When I on fav'rite nymphs bestow</br>Of young Desire the hallow'd glow,</br>They roll no fond inviting eye,</br>Nor heave th' uncover'd bosom high,</br>Vainly to win the coxcomb gay,</br>Or heart of guileless swain betray.</br>To nature true, their breasts arise,</br>Soft-beaming languish fills their eyes;</br>Bright on their cheek the blush is seen,</br>Fine passions struggle in their mein;</br>And, as my rising power they feel,</br>The more they study to conceal</br>These beauties, Love and I reveal.

"With me yon beaming car ascend,</br>I'll bring you to me fav'rite grove;</br>There on your footsteps shall attend,</br>Unseen, the Pleasures born of Love;</br>Around you Beauty's train shall rove,</br>Nor anguish more your bosom rend."

CANTO II.</br>Here ceased the sweet Enthusiast's song</br>To warble from her plaintive tongue;</br>And tow'rd her region of delight,</br>Attended by the buoyant gale,</br>Anon she moved her chariot bright</br>From the bleak solitary dale.</br>And now I spied the well-known glade,</br>The eddy stream, and neigh'bring bower,</br>Where morning, noon, and evening hour,</br>Following Love, I blithly strayed,</br>Or by her side unweeting played:</br>Among the curious groves was ANNA seen,</br>Stalking along the velvet green,</br>With haughty step, in white brocade,</br>O'er which a wealth of gauzes played;</br>High shone above her towering locks</br>Gems, feathers, flow'rs, fresh from the box:</br>Attendant on her walk, a train</br>Of simpering coxcombs, pert and vain;</br>And as she threw her smiles around,</br>Each hollow heart return'd a sigh,</br>Like feathered shafts her glances wound—</br>But lo!  the wounded never die.</br>"The gay coquette" (my Guardian said,</br>As slow her chariot left the glade),</br>"In glow of youth and beauty's pride,</br>A while in triumph high may ride;</br>Yet soon will Age his wrinkles shed,</br>Soon Hope, and every charm, be fled,</br>And never, never will she know</br>The joys from mutual love that flow;</br>Nor ever in a blooming race</br>A mother's graces will she trace:</br>And when she mingles with the dead,</br>No tear shall o'er her dust be shed;</br>No daughter for her guardian mourn,</br>No widow'd lover clasp her urn."

But now these scenes 'gan to recede;</br>And soon we pass'd a level mead,</br>Where many a village nymph and swain,</br>With summer's gayest flow'rets crown'd,</br>To Minstrelsy's enlivening strain</br>Skimm'd along the verdant ground,</br>Hand in hand a jocund train;</br>As from the welkin's western way</br>Glanc'd the sun's departing ray,</br>And gradual o'er the varying sky</br>Evening rose in crimson dye.</br>Scarce had we left the sportive green</br>Till a deep vale 'gan to appear,</br>Whence shrieks of anguish thrill'd the ear:</br>Here, glimm'ring thro' the trees, was seen,</br>By the red moon, a new-made grave;</br>Close by it mumur'd the dark wave;</br>And o'er it hung funereal yew,</br>Shedding the midnight's drizzly dew,</br>Among whose boughs the Nightingale</br>Sung ELUSING'S plaintive tale;</br>To sooth a love-lorn frantic maid,</br>Who on the dank moss-turf was laid.</br>As o'er her heaving bosom bare</br>Wav'd her black dishevell'd hair,</br>Along the grave, in silent mood,</br>Myrtle and willow-leaves she strew'd;</br>In wildest frenzy now she star'd;</br>Now her dead lover's cries she heard;</br>And now the Maniac weep'd aloud.

Tho' Sympathy's convulsive sighs</br>My bosom tore, and tho' my eyes</br>Could not supply a pitying tear,</br>Yet much I wish'd to linger here;</br>Some gentle solace to afford</br>The maid, who wail'd her murther'd Lord:</br>But soon our ether-chariot rose</br>Far o'er this scene of human woes.

Now Morning from the orient gleam'd,</br>And now in fuller radiance stream'd,</br>Disclosing to my ravish'd sight</br>A landscape, breathing gay delight—</br>The grassy vale, the swelling hill,</br>While southward fell a mazy rill,</br>Adown the steep, thro' mantling bowers,</br>And lawns o'erspread with fresh-blown flowers;</br>Whence Zephyr on his downy wing</br>Wafted the fragrance of the Spring:</br>Along the dewy-beaming green,</br>Boldly beside the crested deer,</br>Many a sporting hare was seen,</br>And snowy lambkins bleating near.</br>Meanwhile was heard the distant low</br>Of herds upon the mountain brow;</br>The hum of bees, the neigh'bring rills</br>Echoing adown the little hills;</br>The cooing of the turtle-dove,</br>And vernal melodies of love</br>From every minstrel of the grove:</br>Hard by yon copse of briar-bushes</br>The blackbirds chanted to the thrushes;</br>The red-breast, and the linnet gray,</br>Shook the bloomy hawthorn spray;</br>While overhead the lark was borne:</br>As higher in the sky he rose</br>His breast with fuller transport glows,</br>In sweeter strains his welcome flows</br>To the returning beam of Morn.</br>Soon as we reach'd the inmost glade,</br>My Guardian to a neigh'bring shade</br>Slowly withdrew; while on my ear</br>Softly flow'd her accents clear:

"Beneath yon roof of twisted vines,</br>On daisied bank a Nymph reclines;</br>Tho' many a love-inspiring grace</br>Smile sweetly on my JULIA'S face;</br>And tho' young Genius coy disclose</br>The mind replete with Fancy's glow,</br>The flowers of Taste in vernal blow,</br>And every charm the Muse bestows;</br>Yet lovelier seem'd the plaintive air</br>Of Innocence divinely fair;</br>The eye with mildest glories beaming,</br>Whence oft the tear of pity streaming;</br>The living blush, the soul refin'd,</br>True image of my heav'nly mind:</br>For to my fav'rite, when a child,</br>I once unveil'd my highest charms;</br>In extacy the Infant smil'd,</br>And wanton'd in her mother's arms.</br>Now breathing from yon echoing grove,</br>I catch her plaintive strains of love:</br>O'er Harley's tale now she reclines,</br>Wetting with tears the simple lines</br>Which I inspir'd:  And as arise</br>The tender scenes to Fancy's eyes,</br>The Fairy's mimic wand, unseen,</br>Softly pencils Harley's mien,</br>Imparting each peculiar grace</br>That in your features she can trace.</br>My heav'nly Presence shall entrance</br>Your thoughts no longer; straight advance</br>To yon retreat; there you shall prove</br>The soft return of JULIA'S love;</br>And there her bosom first shall know,</br>That highest blessing I bestow,</br>Friendship, sublim'd by Passion's glow."

She paus'd.  Then step by step withdrew,</br>Till mingling with the welkin blue.</br>I woke; and wand'ring by a brook,</br>Sudden the rustling breeze display'd,</br>Embosom'd in a flowery nook,</br>JULIA in flowing chintz array'd.</br>The woodland-choir above her sung,</br>As o'er th' endearing page she hung.</br>Her cheek with light of Beauty glow'd,</br>Which ever soft'ning feature show'd;</br>Her full breasts rose beyond controul,</br>As from her wishful glances stole</br>The tend'rest feelings of the soul.</br>Smiling the Graces round her sported;</br>And here young Innocence resorted,</br>Of gay, and sympathetic mien,</br>Whose form is oft by Poet seen,</br>While slumb'ring by some wizard stream,</br>Beauty employs his blissful dream.

Not sooner scuds the timid fawn</br>Along the verdure-mantled lawn,</br>When, breathing on his shrinking ear,</br>The breeze has whisper'd danger near;</br>Nor swifter o'er the dimpled stream</br>Glances the Sun's returning beam</br>At morn — than JULIA'S charms impart</br>A glow of rapture to my heart;</br>Than the full pulse, and trembling frame,</br>And short quick pant reveal the flame.</br>In transport long the maid I view'd,</br>Yet could not on her thoughts intrude;</br>So pure the spirit of Reserve,</br>Glowing breath'd thro' ev'ry nerve.</br>At length, it chanc'd a favourite lamb,</br>Around whose neck the eglantine</br>JULIA had wove with jessamine,</br>While gamb'ling by its placid dam,</br>Vain of the gay embroid'ring wreath,</br>Fell heedless in the bourn beneath.</br>As welt'ring 'midst the surgy brook,</br>Crying it threw a wistful look</br>Around, when from the copse I hied,</br>And sav'd it from the whelming tide.</br>Up sprung the Nymph — her glance caught mine;</br>My heart beat high with bliss divine.</br>The light of youth now disappear'd,</br>Now transient glow'd on JULIA'S mien,</br>Trembling, she eye'd me with regard,</br>Till gradual rose the smile serene;</br>And with the languish of her eye,</br>And native blush of Modesty,</br>Own'd sympathetic Love was nigh.

While yielding to my bland caress,</br>Her swelling breasts I timid press,</br>Ah!  many a tender thought arose,</br>And ardent wish'd I to disclose—</br>Each feeling, as it ling'ring hung</br>Mute, on my fascinated tongue.</br>But soon appear'd a beaming cloud,</br>"Slow-sailing down the yielding sky,"</br>Whence straight in tuneful accents flow'd</br>The voice of SENSIBILITY.

"My fav'rite Pair!  no other vow,</br>Or Heav'n, or Nature, asks of you;</br>For, to your bosoms I impart</br>Love's tend'rest unison of heart.</br>Affection's pure ethereal fire</br>My spirit ever shall inspire;</br>And, as you own my soft controul,</br>Thro' ev'ry vein shall transport roll,</br>And Pleasure's smile illume your soul."</br>
